newsitem.title: FINLAND: Finnish forest industry says pulp price may fall.
newsitem.headline: Finnish forest industry says pulp price may fall.

text.p: The Finnish Forest Industries Federation said on Monday that the price of pulp may fall further.
"The latest observation is that the price of pulp may fall further," Matti Korhonen, managing director of the federation, told a news conference on the industry's outlook.
"At the end of the year (1996) Norscan producers' pulp inventories totalled 1.9 million tonnes, which did not allow price increases," the federation said in a statement.
"The winter season is problematic because winter inventories cannot be unloaded," Korhonen said.
Overall, last year was poor for the forest industry, he said, adding: "The upturn expected since the autumn has not materialised."
Earlier, he told Finnish television that the upturn might not start "until the snow melts." In Finland, winter snow normally starts melting around mid-April.

In 1996, the value of Finnish forest industry exports fell 10 percent to 53.3 billion markka. The industry's output volume of paper and paperboard fell 4.6 percent to 10.44 million and pulp output fell 8.1 percent to 9.7 million tonnes, the federation said in the statement.

"Paper production fell by nearly seven percent. This drop was the biggest since the recession of 1975. The capacity utilisation rate in the paper sector was 84 percent last year, down from 92 percent in 1995," it said.
Magazine paper output fell 13 percent and newsprint output seven percent while fine paper output rose four percent.
"The price of fine paper rose slightly in late 1996, but the average price was 20 percent lower than in 1995," it said.
